name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Good morning, everybody, and a very warm welcome to Commissioner Cecilia Malmström. It is a wonderful, beautiful, day, the Hungarian national day, so I am extremely happy to welcome you all to our plenary sitting today.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The first item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Bernd Lange, on behalf of the INTA Committee, on the implementation of the Conflict Zone Minerals Regulation (O-000017/2018 - B8-0009/2018) (2018/2557 RSP), by Linda McAvan in the on behalf of the Committee, the oral question to the Commission on accompanying measures in relation to minerals from conflict zones (O-000016/2018 - B8-0008/2018) (2018/2542 (RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: author. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. A year ago, we adopted the new legislation on the fair use of so-called conflict minerals. This was an important step in the context of a value-based trade policy and also away from a trade policy based only on bilateral agreements towards a focus on value chains. This is just the right approach in the face of global value chains. I would also like to thank the Commission for the very productive monitoring of the negotiations. This has certainly been a great success for all the institutions of the European Union. This legislation will fully enter into force on 1 January 2021. We deliberately took a little longer because this is a new approach — a new approach that requires responsible management, corporate due diligence for the entire value chain. This is, of course, something new that has not yet been tested in practice. And that's why this longer period is right. We have focused on the four main so-called conflict minerals — tantalum, tungsten, tin, and gold — that are currently being obtained in regions burdened by civil wars and other conflicts, where people are forced to force children to mine these minerals. I believe that anyone who has gold jewelry or a smartphone should be sure that the materials used here, do not result from forced labor, from brutal situations. That's why these four minerals cover the entire value chain with a duty of care, from the mine to the melting plant to the product. These four minerals that we have focused on account account for 35% of global trade, 35% is a lot. In this respect, we will also take an important step in the global context. And now the two have Committees submitted this debate and the question for oral answers, because, of course, some steps need to be taken in the preparations for January 2021. Legislation is the first step, but then there are some steps in terms of implementation. And, of course, we want to design legislation in such a way that there are no loopholes that will allow this good legislation to be undermined. In this respect, we want to ensure that the maximum of this positive effect is truly appreciated. Incidentally, to industry: we have, of course, set 1 January 2021, but this does not prevent anyone from applying the legislation ahead of schedule. The main issues focus on the area: what is the real situation with the recognition of voluntary industrial schemes? We have said in legislation that if certain industries want to move forward and have reliable autonomous industrial schemes, this will be recognised. Are there any studies there already and are there any agreements with the OECD to take into view certain schemes? Then, within the framework of legislation, we also asked for accompanying measures, both as regards small and medium-sized enterprises here with us, which are certainly experiencing particular difficulties, and with regard to the question of how to provide development policy assistance on the ground. The transparency of the data was also an important consideration. This is about the data base, whether a certain pre-development has already taken place. And finally, of course, I said that 35% of minerals are recorded, but that means 75% is not covered. What is the process of working with other countries around the world to ultimately capture 100%?

name: Linda McAVAN
text: author. – Madam President, before talking about the technical side of the conflict minerals supply chain, it’s maybe worth pausing and remembering why we are having this legislation at all. Because it’s not a technical issue, it’s about human rights. It’s about combating violence against women and girls, and it’s about improving governance in some of the world’s most fragile and poorest countries.  I’ve been an MEP for almost 20 years and I’ve seen many great speakers in this Chamber. But one of the most memorable was Dr Denis Mukwege, who came here in November 2014. Dr Mukwege spoke passionately about his country, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and about its enormous mineral wealth. He made a direct link between the illegal exploitation of that wealth and the appalling abuse of human rights and violence against women, the rapes and worse of women and girls, who he treats in his hospital in Panzi. I visited the hospital in Panzi and if you can go, please go, it is an extraordinary place, and Dr Mukwege is an extraordinary man.  What he said struck a chord with many of us here, because back in November 2014 Parliament was examining the proposal from the Commission on how to tackle conflict minerals. We had, to be frank, a rather thin proposal from the Commission, which talked about voluntary measures. I’m looking at Judith Sargentini here, and I have to pay her tribute because she fought for many years for legislation in this field before the last elections. But when Dr Denis Mukwege came, it did have an impact. People started to listen. Parliament listened. You listened, Madam Commissioner, Neven Mimica listened, and eventually the Council even listened and we brought in a mandatory system. And now we have to make that mandatory system work.  We are seeing some progress. I would like to pay tribute to Global Witness, and Amnesty International as well, for pushing us along this path. Global Witness published a report last summer. They surveyed a number of mineral-exporting companies, showing that whereas none reported on due diligence in 2013, almost 50% were reporting by last year, and as the legislation takes hold we expect that number to increase. But the report also showed gaps. Only one gold-exporting company was reporting, and the standard of reporting was extremely weak. That’s where our accompanying measures come in. We need to work with these companies to improve reporting and standardise the content. And we need to do more. The 2014 Commission communication lists 14 areas of work. Late last year, we saw the first Development Cooperation Instrument (DCI) proposal come on stream, it was a good project, and what we are asking today is a timetable for the other proposals which need to come between now and 2021. We need projects with companies – yes – but also with governments. We need projects with civil society, with women’s organisations. And we need the EU to step up its diplomacy. We need to be asking these countries, when we have our political dialogue, what they are doing about the due diligence on conflict minerals, and we need to be asking our Member States as well what they are doing to ensure that this legislation is implemented and that the OECD due diligence guidelines are actually effective across the European Union. We need regular reporting back to this Parliament, and we also need the Council and the public at large to be kept informed.  Why do we need to do that this? We need to it because we need to make this legislation work. We need to deliver on the promise made in Addis Ababa on financing for development and on ensuring more domestic resource mobilisation. If we have legal channels for mineral exports, we will have better tax revenues in some of these countries. We need to deliver on sustainable development goals, not least of which is SDG 16 on good governance, and this would help tackle corruption and stop fuelling armed conflicts. Most of all, we need to do it because we owe it to the people, to the women and the children whom Denis Mukwege spoke about and whom he treats in his hospital. It would be a real legacy of this Parliament and your work, Commissioner, over the last five years, if we could make sure that this legislation takes hold and is effective, and if we could see a change in the future.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me to congratulate you on your national day.  This is indeed very important legislation. We can jointly be proud of it. We worked hard together, and it is – as the two rapporteurs have said – the clear evidence of the value-based trade agenda. It is complex and difficult, so we need to have an integrated approach. I appreciate this possibility to update you on what we are doing to prepare for the full implementation of this. The regulation stipulates that the requirement of EU importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold shall apply as from January 2021, so that companies, Member States and the Commission can efficiently prepare. There are a series of actions explicitly set out in the regulation, and we are busy finalising them. For instance, the guidance to help companies on the identification of conflict-affected and high-risk areas and other supply-chain risks they may consider in their due diligence process.  We are also preparing guidance for the Member States’ competent authorities in their upcoming enforcement activities, in particular, the so-called ex-post checks on importers and a delegated regulation on the methodology that the Commission will use to recognise and validate industry due diligence schemes, which would be instrumental in ensuring that the regulation is operational.  These initiatives are well advanced and they should be adopted already in the first half of this year. In the subsequent step, building on these initiatives, the Commission will adopt and implement the act establishing a list of global responsible smelters and refiners and find a first indicative non-exhaustive list of conflict-affected and high-risk areas from external expertise already next year, which is well in advance of the deadline.  In addition to the initiatives explicitly mentioned in the regulation, we are also advancing the accompanying measures, and we are fully committed to honour the promises of a more political nature that we made during the negotiations on this regulation. In this regard, I would like to emphasise four work streams that we know are important for you.  Firstly, the measures to support SMEs: both of the honourable rapporteurs mentioned the oral question put, to support SMEs in their efforts to implement policies for responsible sourcing of minerals. In January this year, the Commission finalised our study on the support system for SME supply chain due diligence. On this basis, by the end of next year the Commission will deliver an online tool designed to help SMEs in their due diligence efforts. This will be available to SMEs in the EU that want to develop and implement due diligence of mineral supply chains, irrespective of whether they have the obligation or not under the regulation. Particular attention will be paid to the competitiveness aspect of SMEs applying due diligence.  Of particular relevance to SMEs will be the translation of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) guidance into all EU languages, which the Commission will provide as early as the spring of this year. Secondly, the measures to foster uptake of responsible sourcing policies among downstream companies. Companies producing goods, including tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, but which do not themselves import the metals and minerals to the EU, do not have legal obligations under the regulation. Nevertheless, it is important that also these so-called downstream companies consider responsible sourcing as far as possible. Last year, the Commission published non-binding guidelines on how to implement the directive on non-financial reporting, explaining that companies are expected to disclose relevant information, in particular on conflict mineral supply chain due diligence. These include notably companies that are active in the downstream. Later this year, we will also make available an online transparency platform where downstream companies can showcase their work on due diligence and exchange best practices. This transparency exercise would be very much welcomed by civil society organisations. In addition, the aforementioned efforts to support SMEs will also be available to downstream companies.  Thirdly, the measures taken to provide the necessary funding for projects on the ground, I would like to highlight a few. We have support to the project promoting responsible supply chains in the area of conflict minerals, which was approved in December 2017. It will foster cooperation between producer and consumer countries on responsible sourcing of minerals through the European Partnership on Responsible Minerals. That is EUR 5.4 million. We have also supported the OECD’s important work on due diligence and responsible sourcing to the tune of EUR 4 million for the period 2014-2019. We have supported the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region for regional initiatives against the illegal exploitation of natural resources. That is EUR 3 million that we paid before, with an indicative amount of a further EUR 3 million for the next stage of the initiative. We also provide support to artisanal and small-scale gold and diamond mining in Burkina Faso, Côte d’Ivoire and the Central African Republic, to the tune of around EUR 4 million. We are considering projects in a number of African countries. We have a maximum here of EUR 4 million. These important financial efforts are in line with the commitment I made to you, together with my colleague, Commissioner Mimica, and of course Vice-President Mogherini, in a letter that we sent to you in March 2015.  Moreover, in implementing these measures, the Commission and the External Action Service attach great value to the multi-stakeholder approach. So we are working closely with industry and civil society.  Fourthly and finally, I would like to stress the important work we have to encourage third-country producers and consumers of minerals and metals to adopt and implement policies for the responsible sourcing of minerals based on the OECD guidelines. Our efforts here are based on three pillars: firstly, we have senior-level technical dialogues that have been carried out over the last two years with major economies in countries of special relevance. This includes, for instance, China, India, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the United Arab Emirates. In this regard, our outreach, together with the OECD secretariat, has delivered tangible results in China, where they have adopted guidelines on the responsible sourcing of minerals, and also in India, where there have been various initiatives launched on the responsible sourcing of gold, in particular.  Secondly, there are proposals to include references to responsible sourcing of minerals based on the OECD guidelines in our free-trade agreements, for instance with Mexico.  Thirdly, substantial support, including funding, for the OECD’s work on the responsible sourcing including promotion and awareness-raising across the globe in producing and consuming countries alike.  You can see that we have worked a lot since we concluded our common work here. Many strands of work, an integrated approach that can deliver but also inspire similar initiatives in other important markets. Thank you again for the opportunity to discuss this with you.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President! Happy birthday to celebrate the national holiday of the Lady of the country! Commissioner, good morning! We discussed other things here last night, so I respect you are with us this early morning. As rapporteur, from the Committee on Development, of the opinion to the Conflict Minerals Regulation, I postulated the introduction of accompanying measures to support and control due diligence in the supply chain of minerals in the countries of origin. From the point of view of our committee, this is very important. As the Commissioner said, the first accompanying measure derived from the Development Cooperation Funding Instruments (DCI) covers only part of the 14 action areas listed in the 2014 Communication. The Commissioner also mentioned the plans and links. Does the Commission intend to present additional accompanying measures covering all other areas in this Communication? I'll also ask a more interesting question about the schedule: what will it look like temporal? You've also spoken about the budget, but will there be any links? The action plan refers to interesting synergies with the European External Investment Plan. What synergies are exactly about, and how will they be related? Finally: are there other accompanying measures financed from instruments other than the financing instrument for development cooperation?

name: Maria ARENA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, the Socialist and Democratic Group — as you know — has been a strong supporter of this legislation and, in particular, with regard to the obligation of this legislation and not the voluntary approach. I would also like to join Bernd Lange on his thanks to the European Commission, because we were able to work together to amend the original proposal and make it mandatory, despite the many obstacles that existed in the various discussions. Legislation has put at the heart of the mechanism the recognition of industrial patterns, which are truly a key element in legislation. However, a corruption and money laundering scandal broke out in 2016 on the refinery and metals that were certified in an LBMA industrial scheme until 2017. This case shows the limitations of the functioning of industrial schemes and, in particular, the lack of transparency of industrial schemes at present. My questions are of three orders. Firstly, in view of this lack of transparency in industrial schemes, will you require them to align fully, as requested in the negotiations, with the OECD principles, namely the public and detailed declaration to give access to the entire information? Secondly, are you going to conduct in-depth analyses using audit practices, by sample, in the case of these industrial schemes? Third, will you ensure that companies remain individually responsible for their due diligence when they do not adhere to a scheme as such? Ensuring the effectiveness of these schemes is really essential if legislation is to be effective. I will now come to the accompanying measures. I read yesterday, in a document provided to us, that entitled “European Partnership for Responsible Minerals”, which brings together experts to work upstream, i.e. in mining mines, is financed by DG DEVCO in the amount of more than €5 million. This initiative brings together stakeholders, such as Intel, Apple and Philips. Can you tell me to what extent these actors also finance this action?

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, the problem is not solved by strict policing and regulations adopted outside Africa. Besides, from the beginning of the history of mankind, wars were fought for 3TG and other precious metals and weapons manufacturing materials. The Trojan War was not about a fine Helen but about the gold of Lydia and Phrygia. Cyprus is constantly changing conquerors for copper, gold, vast forests and now for its natural gas. History repeats itself. Africa has huge deposits of precious metals exploited for the benefit of third parties and not the African peoples, and the regions where precious minerals exist are fields of harsh conflict. If mineral wealth were to be exploited honestly and transparently, Africa would be the richest continent and could escape poverty, underdevelopment and dependence on foreign aid. Instead, the exploitation of mineral wealth is the cause of bloody conflicts, wars and massacres. Africa remains underdeveloped and continues to spend the profits from its precious ore to buy weapons that Africans kill each other with. It does not spend its income on education, democracy and the welfare of the population, but on the violation of all human rights, especially children's rights, in a wild form of modern slave trade, as the World Bank for the Republic of Congo has catavaltically denounced in 2008. The European Parliament in 2007 took a very important step: it tried with the accompanying measures to regulate the marketing of 3TG, especially for production from conflict areas. However, the European Union has a great responsibility for the whole situation. So what are we doing as a European Parliament and what does the Commission do besides half-measures?

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, by adopting the responsible sourcing regulation on 17 May 2017, we wanted to break the link between the marketing of minerals and the financing of conflicts. This was a dramatic step forward in regulating responsible procurement. But there is obviously a need to take vigorous accompanying measures to improve local governance. Commissioner, thank you for your personal commitment and for the Commission's efforts to address Parliament's concerns. I regret, however, that the amounts allocated to accompanying measures are mainly committed by the Commission and very little by the Member States: 20 million over the period 2016-2020 for all the countries concerned, this obviously seems to me to be totally insufficient. These are therefore very small amounts. I would add that nowhere I see the commitment of a permanent political dialogue with the partner countries. I express the same concern as my colleague Maria Arena about the lack of transparency in industrial patterns — I will not return to that. Of course, I would like to thank DG DEVCO for committing €5 million in 2017 for measures aimed at supporting local authorities, strengthening local communities, supporting the private sector in implementing due diligence, but this is obviously insignificant compared, of course, to needs. I think we need a lot more, and we will be careful about it. Obviously, I regret. We have already gone very far, we have achieved significant progress, but we could have gone much further, especially in terms of traceability of all the companies involved. Madam, I obviously trust you to follow this file and we will certainly come back to the expense to see where the amounts are, we hope much more important, to really resolve this issue.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (NL) Mr President, I am pleased that European legislation is going to restrict trade in conflict minerals. But I am pleased with some comments. One of them is: I did not want to restrict imports of raw materials alone. I also wanted to help regulate consumer goods, such as our inseparable mobile phone. That didn't work out. The other thing I regret is that it has to take so long. America has already imposed import restrictions in 2013, and we are actually not going to actually check until 2021. I think that's a pity. Anyway, we got it. And now we need to make sure that by 2021 it is also in place and properly implemented. My questions to the Commissioner are: how do we ensure that the development money available for that implementation does not just go to companies to get their bureaucracy in order, but that mining communities in countries like Congo and their governments are given the opportunity to which companies also really control? The next question is this: what have we done ourselves, what has the European Commission done to change the procurement rules so that we, too, do not buy computers without knowing what minerals and metals are contained in them, and do you also impose that kind of requirements on service contracts of commercial providers? That's what I'd like to know. One final point, if you may. There is support for regulation here to curtail trade that violates human rights. Textiles, for example. Please do something with that, because the next step must be another product.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Fellow Members! Let's keep the time limits. I'm sorry, I know it's a very important question and it's a lot to talk about, but to be fair to each other, let's keep the D'Hond thing. I was trying to give you the time by letting everyone get past it. Let us adhere to it so that the next items on the agenda can also start in time.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I would like to address you, Mrs Malmström from the Commission, but also to the absent Council, because I miss it in this very important debate on an important legislative procedure: there are now more than four million internally displaced persons in Congo. According to UNICEF, 13.1 million people are dependent on humanitarian aid there, including 7.8 million children. These are destinies in the struggle for control of raw materials, and their sale to Europe and Asia makes the warlords, but also traders and buyers rich. That's how guns are financed. We have already discussed this importance here on various occasions. I ask you: what specific information does the Commission have on the associated delivery routes and cash flows? If you do not have this information, what do you do to get this information? The more than 360 companies in the Responsible Minerals Initiative have acted almost ahead and have substantially adapted their policies to the OECD guidelines. This week they already delivered the new reporting tools to their companies. In June 2018, i.e. this year, their use will become mandatory. When are we coming? Mrs Malmström, precisely because I was so happy at the time that we worked together and were able to achieve a lot, that today I am concerned that sceptics and brakers would like to let the initiative disappeared. This also includes the transparency requirement that has already been mentioned. How far has the Commission come in its accompanying support measures? How do we prepare for implementation in Central Africa? How do we prepare companies in the European Union? Where are the Member States? There's still a lot of work to be done! Mr Michel has spoken about this. Have positions been set up? Are the required customs lines legally prepared to meet the Regulation to be able to implement? Finally, a suggestion to all of us: we should be talking about the downstream commitments now.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, ultimately, the goal of the developing world is long-term economic growth that is sustainable and which will lead to the reduction of poverty. This cannot occur in an environment where corruption is commonplace. Where corruption and uncertainty are rife, few entrepreneurs will risk their money in business ventures where corrupt officials help themselves to the proceeds, so a lack of investment leads to stagnation, and a fall in investment kills off any growth.  Because there is no trade parity with sub-Saharan Africa, the true value of the natural resources is not met, and it is all too easy for the black market economy and criminal manipulation of the nation’s resources to happen. Despite over USD 1 trillion in aid from the West to Africa over the last 50 years, the situation has, in fact, become worse. There is a correlation. We continue to call for fair trade with Africa, and not aid. If we allow Africa to develop supply chains by cutting back tariffs and trade barriers on finished and manufactured products, rather than distorting supply chains by forcing Africa to export raw materials, there would not be a market to be exploited in conflict minerals. You would see professionals filling up the entire supply chain from engineering to marketing, which would improve the whole economy and force the people in power to manage their resources more effectively, making corruption much harder.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, I would just like to tell you that when you do not hold the time, it is an injustice to others. So either we all slip — but then I don't see how that is possible — or you give everyone the time it takes. I want to tell you. With regard to this issue of conflict ores, I believe that if there is conflict ores, there is conflict, I would even say there is conflict because there are minerals. That is, we are in geopolitical games and power games. I would point out that the operation rebellion in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) around 1995 — and I was there — was manipulated, completely conducted by the United States and that all this was done, indeed, to have control of these minerals. So we must always place this matter in its geopolitical context of war in order to take control of minerals. Certainly, we need self-certification, of course we must have more transparency, but my colleague Maria Arena — and here I agree with her — has clearly shown the limits of this industrial scheme and how it can be perverted. Take the DRC: we are never talking about Mr Kagame, but he occupies this country and takes these minerals very gently when he is considered a very democratic man and, moreover, this with the support of Canadian, American and German companies. Nobody talks about this, how will your self-certification bring something? What we have to do is put things in their place. There can be no freedom of trade for very sensitive minerals. We must renationalize, we must put States back at the centre and balance with the Security Council in order to take effective control of these raw materials and not allow free trade to happen because we will always have a devotion.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Mr... and your remark, which is why I allowed the representatives of the parties to speak further in the first round. We are now listening to Mr Synadinos in one minute on behalf of the Independents. Here you go.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the implementation of the planned implementing stages will be delayed under reasonable pretexts. Obviously, the interest of those seeking only economic gain and competitive access to precious minerals and metals with high added technological value is commensurate with the stake. The brutal reality is that importing mineral resources from conflict areas often costs less than adopting reforms based on the principles of the circular economy. Their mining and marketing practices in terms of provocative profiteering refer directly to discounts on morality and human dignity. The Commission must, as a minimum, implement the half-measures already adopted, including the inclusion of miners under the rule of law and by drawing on the OECD and United Nations guidelines and principles concerning due diligence requirements in the supply chain and labour and human rights.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I will speak for the rapporteur from the EPP, Iuliu Winkler, and ask the questions he would have liked to ask, as he cannot be here.  Firstly, has there been any feedback on the Handbook for Economic Operators detailing the criteria on conflict-affected and high-risk areas?  Secondly, what is the state of play on the Member States’ competent authorities? Has the deadline of 9 December been met? If not, has the Commission taken any steps to assist in the establishment of these key national bodies?  Thirdly, is the translation process of the OECD Due Diligence Guidance making progress?  Fourthly, likewise, has the Commission taken steps to support SMEs in their preparatory efforts for complying with the due diligence requirements?  Lastly, what is the Commission approach in promoting OECD due diligence standards and what related outreach actions have been undertaken in this regard? Have major strategic partners shown an interest or already taken concrete steps in establishing similar standards for due diligence in order to prevent the financing of conflicts through the trade in illicitly mined minerals?

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, talking about traceability of conflict minerals, tantalum, tin, gold and tungsten, means having ethics and transparency at heart. Responsible procurement and mandatory traceability is a must. Illegal minerals trade fuels outbreaks of violence that tend to eternise. The adoption of the regulation is recent, and we have taken note of the accompanying measures defined by the Commission in cooperation with the OECD. 2021, when obligations will apply to importers in the European Union, came upon us. All mineral extractive-commercial undertakings must be adapted to the measures, including local undertakings established in the extraction contexts. The Commission must demonstrate the same degree of ambition as Parliament in drafting accompanying measures. Our involvement is essential, as it becomes urgent to take additional measures, including small local workers as preferred recipients. There also needs to be a thorough analysis of how to extend the responsible supply of other minerals outside the regulation, such as cobalt.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, the Conflict Minerals Regulation was adopted one year ago, but its requirements will start to apply only as of 2021. Whilst we are eager to hear what steps and measures the Commission has taken, there are already some very good initiatives coming from the Member States, and I am happy to announce that Finland and Sweden just this week announced that together they would prepare a sustainability certificate that would cover the whole supply chain – mining, production, use and recycling of minerals.  This is an excellent initiative because the supply and sustainability chain should not end with the consumer, but should also take into account the reuse and recycling of minerals. Electric cars and other new consumer products are increasing the demand for rare minerals every year and not just in Europe, but worldwide, so this is a golden opportunity for the EU to set standards for sustainable risk-free supply chains and due diligence requirements.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Madam President, before the adoption of this regulation we already criticized that it was a missed opportunity to have a firm and totally binding law, a law without legal gaps that would give us absolute guarantees that in the European Union we do not import blood minerals. Nevertheless, we voted in favour, because we thought that the Conflict Minerals Regulation was in the right direction. Now is the time to assess what the Commission has done with the vote of confidence we gave it. But of the EUR 20 million pledged by the Commission, five and a half have been earmarked for a Dutch initiative with broad private participation. We are honestly concerned about the priority that the Commission is giving to the interests of large companies and corporations. In order to improve the living conditions of mining populations, the needs of victims should be put first. We therefore call for measures and funding to strengthen the governance of the artisanal mining sector, to ensure its coexistence with the industrial sector, promote regularization of the informal sector, create mechanisms for coordination and dialogue among the various actors to ensure coherence, and, of course, to do all this always including local actors. We have the opportunity to export human rights in a real and effective way. Why are we so shy? Who's holding us back? And, in conclusion, I just want to thank Mrs Sargentini for saying that: it is also urgent to address the human rights violations committed in the textile sector.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, all wars are bad, be they trade wars or military wars, and we have heard enough about trade wars in the last couple of weeks. Conflicts are to be avoided, as well. Therefore, it is important that we discuss conflict minerals today and the effect they are having on the world. Great credit is due to the Members here who have taken on this responsibility, together with the Commission. They have made excellent progress. I was interested in the points made by the Commissioner, where she put more emphasis on the ‘carrot’ than on the ‘stick’ in relation to such matters as guidance to Member States, in relation to export checks, support for SMEs and, especially, the online tools and financial support – which is never enough but, at the same time, is significant. She mentioned discussions with India and China to ensure that there is responsible sourcing of minerals, and she has also done a huge amount of work on free-trade agreements, on including a chapter on conflict minerals in them – and she mentioned Mexico. All this is very good but I think we also need to hear a bit more about the ‘stick’.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome the questions related to accompanying measures aimed at the promotion of the implementation of and compliance with due diligence for the minerals’ countries of origin. Indeed, in their joint communication, the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy expressed their commitment to the implementation of accompanying measures for an integrated EU approach to responsible sourcing, with the purpose not only of ensuring a high level of participation by companies in the Union, but also of guaranteeing that a global, coherent and comprehensive approach is put in place in order to promote responsible sourcing from conflict-affected and high-risk areas.  Following the launch of the first development cooperation instrument-funded accompanying measure in late 2017, it is important to assess whether other accompanying measures responding to the objectives encompassed in the joint communication will be designed, and whether these additional measures would cover very relevant aspects such as the implementation of fair taxation for minerals.  Finally, with regards to the actors involved, it is of great importance that the interventions envisaged include local authorities and civil societies as well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Africa is a rich continent with huge deposits of oil, natural gas, mineral wealth, ores, but its peoples are suffering. They are poor, they are unemployed, because ores, diamonds and gold are exploited by multinationals, which make superprofits, and of course where there is wealth, there is also a field of conflict to grab it. So there are areas of war, areas of civil war, where there really is exploitation of minerals and that is where we have child labour. So the intervention that needs to be done in this field is decisive. I think that an intervention for 2021 is specified. It's pretty late. There are half-measures. I think we need to take measures which relate not only to the importation of minerals but also to finished products. We need interventions not for the companies but for the miners themselves. And of course there must be decisive intervention to stop the conflicts in these regions.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, conflict minerals or blood minerals? Between 2018 and 2021, there will be three years in which global and European companies and multinationals, in particular, will continue to make a new version of mineral-exploiting colonialism. It has become clear that the voluntary framework does not work and that many of the minerals that arrive in Europe come from violence, from lack of respect for human rights, from corruption and also from funding to armed groups. Traceability — and we agree with the Commission and the author — is therefore very necessary, but traceability that goes beyond the Due Diligence Guide, which is a system well known to companies; we have verified the websites of many companies that are mineral operators in Congo and on other continents and only 10% apply it. In this intervention, I would also like to stress the importance of mandatory regulation being applied throughout the supply chain and the marketing chain. From here, I would also like to convey my support for the European platform on conflict minerals.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, it is known that gold, tin, tungsten and tantalum are minerals used for the production of high-tech products. The problem is that these minerals are mined in areas mainly in Africa where there are conflicts, there are civil wars, regimes that are corrupt, which oppress the people, use their people, mostly in violation of human rights , as workers and acquire large sums of money, which they do not have for the welfare of their peoples but to buy weapons and continue the wars to control these areas. In this sense, the European Union is very right to intervene in order to find a way of making legislation which will help to prevent this uncontrollable situation. Importers definitely need to follow certain rules — that is correct — but other measures must be taken and the European Union must carry out serious controls so that these measures are not violated.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank Mr Lange and Ms McAvan for putting this on the agenda. There is clearly a huge interest in these questions, and I fully understand that because it is also important to us. This is very important legislation on a serious problem of grave violation of human rights in certain areas. This could contribute, but of course it will not solve the problems fully.  I also understand your impatience on this, but I want to remind you that the legislation has not yet entered into force. I answered many of your questions already in my introductory remarks, but am happy to come back to them. We are now focusing more on the incentives than on the legislation. When that enters into force, then we will have other tools as well.  We are working specifically to help SMEs to prepare for this with our online tool. The translations of the OECD guidelines will be done later this spring. The transparency platform for downstream companies is also targeting SMEs in particular.  We are working closely with our Member States and experts. There are only five Member States who still need to appoint their authority. The others are working on it, as some of you mentioned. There are lots of initiatives happening in the Member States today – we can come back to a fuller list of that at a later stage. There have also been some results from our outreach, for instance we see now that China is adopting legislation and that there are discussions going on in India as well. On the industry scheme alignment, this is done by a delegated act based on the OECD methodology, and yes, there will be shadow audits, but companies do remain individually responsible. On the Apple-Intel participation in the European partnership, it is key here to have a partnership between business, NGOs and governments. They will adequately complement the regulation with technical assistance and good mining practices for small and artisanal miners. On the transparency of schemes, the methodology adopted by, or developed by, the OECD is to recognise industry schemes to make sure that they fully respect the five steps of OECD due diligence guidance, including reporting. This alignment methodology is developed and monitored in conjunction with civil society organisations, including, for instance, the organisation Global Witness, which is very helpful in this regard. The Commission is not financing big private companies. We are focusing financing through a call for proposals on local activities for artisanal and small-scale miners to enhance their socioeconomic capacities, increase their productivity, make them, in due time, eligible to access credits, take care of the gender issue, and help them address the worst cases of child labour affecting the mining areas. There are also proposals to target the capacity of local authorities, so we are really trying to work on a bottom-up approach. Those expected to present proposals for EU funds will mainly be civil society organisations, and many of them have very significant experience in this field. We appreciate this and want to support it. On the Non-financial Reporting Directive, we have made a very clear commitment in this regard as part of the political agreement on the regulation, and we are fully committed to honouring it. The Non-financial Reporting Directive provides that the companies covered by the Directive shall include in their management report the principal risks related to those matters linked to the undertaking’s operations, including business relationship, products or services which are likely to cause adverse impact in these areas and to show how the undertaking manages those risks.  So we specified last year, in non-binding guidelines on non-financial reporting, that companies are expected to disclose relevant information on due diligence to ensure responsible supply chains for tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold.  On this basis, it is clear that the Commission expects companies covered by the directive to include reporting on the responsible sourcing of 3TG. As you know, we are planning a review of the regulation, even though it has not entered into force yet. In that review we could decide to include new minerals – the methodology has been developed to be neutral in that case. We will also make an assessment of whether it is enough or there is a need for new legislative measures, and we will be happy to work with you in this regard.  As you see, we have been doing a lot already to prepare and to make the accompanying measures in order to have all that ready when it finally enters into force. I thank you for your strong interest in this, and I commit, Madam President, honourable Members, regularly to come back and report where we are. I know that the interest is significant, and we promised at the adoption of this that the Commission would keep you regularly informed about what is happening. I remain at your disposal whenever you should wish, and thank you again for this debate.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is closed.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission's statement: 'Action Plan for the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure' (2017/3034 (RSP)

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss our Action Plan on alternative fuels infrastructure. The Commission warmly welcomes the European Parliament’s initiative. As Members of this House, you have already called for a high level of ambition with the adoption of the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive in 2014. The Commission shares this ambition. The provision of a comprehensive, easy-to-use infrastructure for alternative fuels is a key prerequisite for the transition to low-emission mobility. Our first priority was to ensure that the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive is properly implemented in all Member States. That is why we did not hesitate to launch immediate infringement procedures against those Member States not complying with the directive. With the second Mobility Package, of 8 November 2017, we delivered an additional policy stimulus, particularly with our Action Plan on alternative fuels infrastructure. By 2030 more and broader action will be needed. We need a larger part of the existing fleet to run on alternative fuels in order to meet the EU commitments under the Paris Climate Treaty. However, we don’t think that the directive needs to be revised at this stage. The Council and Parliament adopted this directive four years ago as the first ever legal instrument to ensure the promotion of a new market for alternative-fuel vehicles and vessels. Since then, a lot of progress has been made. Yes, the completeness, coherence and ambition of the national policy frameworks vary greatly. Our analysis of the implementation of the directive shows that, on average so far, the planning under the national policy frameworks which Member States had to submit pursuant to the Directive would not meet the level and consistency of ambition that will be needed after 2020, when more vehicles are expected to hit the roads. However, in many places the directive has acted as a catalyst and has stimulated and broadened national planning and strategies. It is therefore time for joint and concerted action, but not for reopening negotiations. So, with the Action Plan on alternative fuels infrastructure, we are now providing an important and very concrete stimulus. We are making available an additional EUR 800 million in the form of innovative financing instruments for the rollout of infrastructure: up to EUR 350 million through the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) ‘Blending’ call and up to EUR 450 million through the CEF Debt or InnovFin instruments. We can already see how the blending of grants and loans under CEF Blending works in practice. Several consortia will now start to roll out fast-charging infrastructure on strategic highways. This is good news for Europe. But there are also less developed parts of Europe where continued support action is needed. Here Member States can benefit from substantial cohesion policy support to accelerate such investments. In the current period of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) EUR 70 billion has been allocated from the Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund for promoting sustainable mobility and transport, including the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure. Through the Action Plan we are also facilitating better collaboration among authorities and market players in relation to good practice. We have already started this process in the form of alternative fuels roadshows in Member States and have received a lot of positive feedback. It is fundamental to stress the need for greater efforts to introduce alternative fuels and clean vehicles. A major lack of infrastructure is no longer a valid argument against it. The basic infrastructure is starting to be put in place in many parts of the European Union. Consumer buy-in depends on quality of choice. It is highly relevant that more vehicle models are being introduced into the market and this is happening quickly. With the second Mobility Package, we have made important proposals to further support market direction, including proposals for a new CO2 emission performance standard and for the revision of the Clean Vehicles Directive. Low-emission and zero-emission vehicles will be favoured by consumers if the infrastructure is not only comprehensive but also easy to use. This is not the case at the moment, particularly not across borders. With the Action Plan, we have now outlined an approach for further discussion with public authorities and market players about needs and approaches for addressing the interoperability of services, including payment services, in the most effective way. We are already supporting authorities on very practical issues of data collection in order to map better the location and availability of charging and filling stations for consumers in Europe. Let me conclude. Together, all the points of action under this Action Plan will help to ensure that we have in place a comprehensive, easy-to-use spec on infrastructure for the recharging and refuelling of alternative-fuel vehicles by 2025.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Commission's decision, through this action plan, to take action on such an important matter as that of the matter of reduction of emissions into the atmosphere in the transport sector, that is, in the context of what has now become the great defendant, the great responsible, the most important responsible for the pollution, behold, is a correct action provided it is carried out in a balanced manner. We, on the one hand, in fact, must ensure the spread of alternative fuels, but we cannot even cross the production industry and even consumers, users, who through a process that if it wasn't gradual they would find themselves having to incur totally off-market costs. Well, the decision to maintain a neutral approach, supporting or funding all possible alternative forms, is very correct and balanced. We will therefore consider over time whether this communication is sufficient or whether new regulatory intervention will also be necessary.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The transport sector is the only sector that continues to increase in emissions, as well as last year or the years before. We once again had 0.5% more greenhouse gases in the mobility sector in 2016 than in 2015, and you pointed out that we already had the Clean Power for Transport Directive of 2014. I have to tell you quite frankly, Commissioner — knowing that this is not your failure because you were not in action at the time — that this was a great opportunity that the Member States destroyed. At the time, with your help in Annex II, we had very clear quantitative targets, which ultimately envisaged building so and so many infrastructures in the various categories by 2020. It is precisely this Annex II that the Council has excluded, so we have now lost four full years. If it had been up to this annex, we would have 800,000 charging stations by 2020. Now we've only 130,000. These are numbers from the Alternative Fuels Observatory, so they are true. That is why this is a great opportunity that we finally missed. I am all the more surprised that the Commission is once again only coming up with an action plan. Legislation is in the process, it's one to 12. The other regions of the world are doing it for us. We know about the development in China, we also know the pressure our industry is under. That is why I invite all of you, especially you as the Commission, to build this infrastructure, the cost of which we have probably calculated, now in the form of a European investment fund. There is an opportunity, with EUR 24 billion, which could be shared by industry and the European Union, to make a rapid ramp-up in terms of infrastructure. If we can't do that — you also have at of CO2 legislation — I do not know if the automotive companies and industry will be able to meet the targets for 2025. Let us therefore be ambitious! With this action plan alone, we will not achieve what we want!

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Commissioner! The transition of the European transport sector to alternative fuels is a process that is already underway. Its course is admittedly still slightly chaotic and is mainly driven by the energy of its greatest enthusiasts and some Member States, but it is hard to underestimate regular progress. The key to success in disseminating green modes of transport is no doubt the availability of terminals and places where such alternative fuel can be refuelled or loaded, whether it be electricity, gas, or hydrogen. The action plan prepared by the Commission rightly recognises the biggest challenges ahead: firstly, adapting existing and still built elements of the TEN-T network to the needs of users of alternative fuels vehicles, secondly, the expansion of the necessary infrastructure in suburban areas where progress in this regard is low. We must not forget that the departure of individual users from combustion cars is the first step. The second step, perhaps much more important, is switching to alternative fuels of the road freight sector. Here, access to adequate infrastructure is already closely linked to the cost-effectiveness and price of such services. Unfortunately, Commissioner, the problem is that this matter has not been addressed in principle in the document in question.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. I believe that most of the people here in Parliament are really on line. I totally agree with Ismail Endired by S&D. We have both worked on this law in the last period, and even then in the trialogue we all quite rightly regretted the fact that the Member States were so unambitious. That is why, like him, I would actually like us to have a different form of new legislation instead of an action plan. I know that's going badly, because the 2022 implementation targets are still around the corner. We can already see, however, that the national plans that need to be presented have been far too little ambitious. There are many reasons. The oil price was too low, so they did not set this in motion. It is also the case that new technologies available on the market are not accepted by consumers because they do not know whether they will be able to drive their vehicle. And this is true for all areas. I know for sure, I strongly promoted LNG at the time for more use of LNG, especially in ships. Many ports are already equipped accordingly. You can do that, of course, more in the north than in the south, because there are different limits. So it's imperative we need to join forces to move faster, and I hope we can do this here.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have heard you, Commissioner, and basically the Commission tells us that if the Member States live up to their commitment to infrastructure, our transport will soon be less polluting. But what if they don't? Two years after the dieselgate scandal, which proved that manufacturers cheated on pollution tests and that the states covered them, you tell us “Trust!” Trust? But today, manufacturers are still slow to get out of diesel to develop clean electric models. Why? Because, according to them, Member States are slow to set up charging stations for electric vehicle batteries and, while they return the bullet, it is Europeans who breathe vapours harmful to their health. Just stop trusting them, Commissioner, reopen the legislation, set binding targets so that tomorrow our transport will be truly clean and that, finally, air pollution drops and disappears forever everywhere in Europe.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, decarbonising the transport sector and meeting the Paris Agreement targets can only be achieved by aligning consumer behaviour with consumer attitudes. It is clear that consumers want the greener transport options but market barriers, and especially a lack of green infrastructure, are leaving us running on the spot. I welcome the Commission’s Action Plan but the national policy frameworks submitted by Member States are lacking in ambition. In my own country’s national action plan, I am most concerned about the infrastructure gaps in terms of charging points for electric vehicles. It is disappointing that the targets for electric recharging points in Ireland’s national policy framework do not correspond with the expected number of electric vehicles in the country. The depressingly low ambitions will get us nowhere and will only set us up to fail, wedding ourselves to a future of fossil-fuel dependency. If we want effective use of investment, support is crucial in making the uptake of electric vehicles a tangible reality.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today I would like to dare and go a little bit out of the box, a little back and a little backwards in time. Almost eighty years ago, an emission-free freight transport solution was already operating in Europe, powered by renewable energy. The Italians in 1938 had difficulties in the supply of fuels and therefore developed a trolleyway that transported materials thanks to modified electric filtrucks (the “trolley trucks”) of Fiat derivation. The Philovia dello Stelvio reached eighty kilometers of extension. It was powered by hydroelectric power. She was decommissioned in 1956. Today the Swedish government, Siemens and Volvo Scania have been experimenting with such a solution for years. The results are excellent, technological advances have improved system reliability by making long-distance electric freight transport possible, otherwise difficult with electrochemical accumulation alone . Costs per kilometre are relatively low and recoverable with operation due to the efficiency of electric traction. It is engaged on existing infrastructure, flexible logistics is possible seamless to the urban centres reachable by moving outside the electrified lines: for short routes with the energy accumulated in batteries during motorway routes, with on-board electric generators or with classic endothermic engines powered by alternative fuels. It is an innovation that does not distort the employment balances of drivers and transport companies. The European Parliament spoke out as early as June 2016 in favour of this solution, but we need vision and coordination at EU level, funds to start infrastructure. These are the great works we would like to leave to the generations to come.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! I wanted to thank the Commissioner very warmly for your information, because today's debate on the Alternative Fuel Infrastructure Action Plan must stimulate — whether it should stimulate — the development of natural gas, hydrogen or electric cars from the grid, and thus also support our fight against air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. These are challenges for Member States, as well as for local governments, business and other stakeholders, without which this cannot be introduced. However, it is easiest to do so at a municipal level, where there is a large transport quota to reduce emissions, if clean technologies are used in municipal vehicles. Financial support for the development of infrastructure that can stimulate public procurement is also important. I welcome the eight-hundred million declaration. And one last point: it seems to me that this is closely coupled with the Clean Vehicle Support Directive. Here the Commission has gone in a very good direction and I think that these objectives should continue to be simplified.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Madam President, in 2020, that is in less than two years, the Opel Corsa electric will start leaving the Figueruelas factory in my region. The Commission had already noted that, by 2020, we would need almost 800 000 refueling stations for alternative fuels. Currently, according to the study that Mr Ertug has published, there are only 120 000. Thus, 680 000 is missing for alternative fuels, and also for electric vehicles, of course. Accounting tells us that it really takes 24 billion to get a sufficient network so that cars that are already on the street and those that are going to continue to be purchased normally by their users. And you, Mr Hahn, only offer us 800 million as an incentive; we need, as you can imagine, a lot more. Therefore, in order to achieve this change we need a fund, which must be urgent, since, in less than two years, it should now be available. And that is why I ask him that, for the new MEC Energía, it does not happen to us like the last time, that we almost had to push to get there to be money; and, of course, more courageous and urgent legislation.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Commissioner, the infrastructure for alternative fuels and the market for environmentally friendly vehicles are a bit like the chicken and the egg. They both look at each other and little happens in the meantime. We are not doing enough to meet the set objectives for basic infrastructure by 2025. With some 130 000 alternative charging and filling points and only 5% vehicles powered by alternative energy, we still have a long way to go. In your action plan, you are right to emphasise 'urgency' and to some point point in the right direction. I would add that we will only make a sustainable transition to low-emission mobility possible if we combine strong ambition with a realistic approach. This is the only way we can fight against global competition in low-carbon vehicles and technologies. I would like to stress the importance of technology neutrality, demand-driven support and an approach that is capable of and flexible in view of rapid technological developments. Finally, I call on the transport sector, the energy sector and all the authorities in the EU to play their part. Only if everyone assumes their responsibilities will European citizens be able to make use of a sound infrastructure.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: Mr President, driving on electricity and hydrogen, that has the future. And in order to achieve the Paris climate targets, we need to move on to alternative fuels. This includes an ambitious policy for the deployment of the infrastructure of these fuels. Action at European level is crucial. I see the action plan as a first step. Let us put the consumer at the centre. Consumers with an electric car must not stop on their way across Europe. Information on the availability of charging stations must be reliable. Information on costs should be available and transparent. And the payment, when loading, when using fuels, must be easy. I call on the Member States, I call on the Commission, I call on industry to take on the roll-out of infrastructure for these alternative fuels with much more ambition. Because only together — putting industry, Commission, Member States, consumers at the heart of this — if we do that, we really make sustainable transport a European success story.

name: Claude TURMES
text: — Madam President, imagine for a moment that I am a Martian and looking at Earth. I have a President Juncker, who says: 'Europe is the leader in green technologies and renewable energy'. And then I have a Chinese president who says, “I am the leader in green technologies, electric cars, renewable energy.” So what does the Martian do? It begins to calculate. Europe doesn't even have 10,000 electric buses. China has 200,000. Europe does not even have 200,000 charging points. China has 1.4 million. We are nowhere and we have a European Commission that does not have the courage to propose strong infrastructure legislation and which suggests to European citizens that, with 800 million, we will make a difference. I say to you as Martian: China is number one and we are ridiculous, and if we continue like that, we will be non-existent in the field of green technologies. It's crying, it takes a completely different effort.

name: Andor DELI
text: — The action plan prepared by the Commission really projects ambitious targets for the period 2020 to 2025, in other words for the next eight years. At the same time, allow me to make a few comments, some of the shortcomings, to draw attention to. First of all, I believe that technological neutrality is the problem in the action plan, because the issue of battery cars and associated infrastructure is being too focused again and again. At the same time, I would remind you that there is a lot of publicly funded research and development taking place all over Europe, with EU money, which also has the right to exist, and that these funds and these invested energies must not be wasted because it is only we rely on battery technology. Diversification in European mobility is important. We don't have to think about moving on a plane. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the Commission's calculations must be realistic and market-based. Indeed, the state aid system, which currently exists in many Member States, is not a permanent thing, and therefore we cannot rely on the calculation that they will remain forever.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, if we want to promote alternative fuels, it is of course very important that consumers have access to a comprehensive charging point network across Europe. This Commission action plan is quite good and demonstrates that the investment needs are really sizeable. There is talk of five billion euros now in just a few years, and another 20 billion should be invested by 2025 when it is talking specifically about electric cars, hydrogen and gas. It is important that we create opportunities for people that electric cars can be charged first and foremost at home because we know that charging is extremely slow. The Energy Efficiency Directive on Buildings now takes this issue into account, but it is also a good course of action that, first and foremost, there is now an effort to bring a network as comprehensive as possible to these core networks, urban areas and suburban areas. It should be remembered that fuel distribution is a market-driven activity. This should also be the case for these alternative fuels in the future, but in order to boost infrastructure, it is justified that we are also trying to redirect investment grants now to this area.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am of the opinion that rather than promoting alternative fuels, with very low environmental benefits, it would be more useful to move towards those that really allow you to achieve the best environmental performance, such as electric, only transient from fossil, biomethane, only transient from methane, and hydrogen from renewable source. The development of charging infrastructure is strategic for the deployment of electric vehicles. But the predisposition of the network of charging balusters must precede and not follow the spread of electric cars, otherwise citizens and businesses will not have the opportunity to use them. Another inconsistency is the requirement of the presence of electric refills only in newly built buildings, which in fact hinders the spread of electric cars. Progress is also possible thanks to technological innovations to support infrastructure. Two processes: smart charging and vehicle-to-grid allow you to control the volume of charging while avoiding overloads to the network during high demand hours, and reverse the flow energy of vehicle batteries, contributing to the stability of the system. It is in this direction that we have to go.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I think that the debate shows the need to take decisive steps for alternative forms of energy. It is a fact that Europe is now fully committed to fossil fuels, and that means increased pollution. We have even seen what happened with Dieselgate, which has shaken the confidence of consumers themselves. The question is whether we have options and those choices of course are natural gas, it is hydrogen and it is electricity. But there will be problems, because we need to invest in, for example, important research, in order to create batteries which can actually charge electric cars without problems, and above all require charging infrastructures for electric vehicles. These do not exist in the European States, and I think that the Commission must intervene decisively here.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 1.5% is the share of electric vehicles in Europe today, 1.1%, the share of sales in 2016. It's still too little if we think, in the face of what are the 35 million dirty diesel vehicles that continue to circulate in our cities and will probably unfortunately continue to do so for several decades. I also think of my country, Italy, together with Hungary and the Czech Republic, we are the only countries to prioritise vehicles powered by natural gas, rather than electric vehicles. It is a vision based on a fossil, illogical and anachronistic model. The 5 Star Movement obviously wants to overcome this logic and catch up in the spread of electric cars, obviously benefiting the environment, the climate and the citizens. It is not just a question of infrastructure: it needs more commitment from car manufacturers who unfortunately, to date, do not give any reassurance and no sufficient guarantee of commitment, even not to losing the competitive advantage because precisely, as Mr Turmes has said, China is now outperforming us in this too.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Madam President! The development of infrastructure related to alternative fuels is an important step to reduce CO2 emissions. We should undoubtedly support it, while not forgetting other alternative fuels. Speaking of this issue, we should remember two matters: firstly, as already mentioned, there are large disparities in the infrastructure (for example, Cyprus has only 35 charging stations, Bulgaria — 100, Poland — 600 and they are mainly located in the centers of major cities, and in small Austria is their 4 thousand, so we can see how big the disproportion is). Secondly, we must not forget that in the countries of the Visegrad Group (Poland or Slovakia) there are numerous manufacturing plants from the traditional automotive sector, producing, for example, internal combustion engines, internal combustion vehicles, components for their production, etc., thanks to which many residents of the population finds a job. As hundreds of thousands of jobs are concerned, time and additional resources for retraining workers is important so that there is no sharp rise in unemployment.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, you have made a very clear presentation of the current situation and, I agree, we have directives, we have alternative fuel directive, we also have the 2017 mobility package. You have made it clear, however, that the implementation of the directive has not reached ambitions regarding the use of alternative fuel within national policies. Could you tell us why? A few examples? Because, I believe that what you said, that states can use funds from the Development Fund, from the Cohesion Fund, does not yet apply in all states. And there's another problem. I think nobody here wants us not to have clean cars. Problem is, we need to figure out how. We need a creative, innovative industry with non-polluting cars, and we need infrastructure. I'm thinking how sad it is now, that we have so little infrastructure - I'm not talking about rural areas - in urban areas. In rural areas it is a disaster and I would not want, by switching to alternative fuels, to disconnect poor areas and rural areas from transport connectivity. Therefore, we need to think very carefully about what measures we can take.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — Madam President, one of the priorities of European transport policy is the decarbonisation of transport. If, of course, we seriously want cleaner vehicles to be able to run in the European Union, then it is important that the deployment of alternative fuel infrastructure takes a truly faster fallout, both on trans-European transport network, so in urban and suburban areas. The adopted Alternative Fuel Infrastructure Directive 2014 sets targets for publicly accessible charging points within national policies. In the Communication already mentioned in May last year, the Commission recognises that the number of public charging stations must increase fundamentally if these targets are to be met. So why, instead of a recast version of the directive, in which it would present proposals for how to achieve this, did it only come up with a non-binding communication?

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, it is true that the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in transport is obvious and, today, an urgent one. There are many solutions available to us and the European Union has a duty to encourage them all, so that they can act in complementarity. There is much talk about electricity and natural gas, but we must not forget about hydrogen, which is now technically controlled. The European Union needs to be much more directive to the states in order to move towards a new territorial structuring of renewable and alternative energy supplies. Manufacturers also have their responsibility, but the European Union must set an example and not only provide much more meaningful financial incentives than the one proposed here, but also genuine binding legislation, which must be put in place as quickly as possible. Naturally, the European Union must also encourage research and continue to work on these issues of energy alternatives.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, at European Union level, but also at global level, we are facing an overwhelming majority of the propulsion systems of internal combustion cars, systems using conventional fuels. Their burns result in the emergence of polluting emulsions, which have a harmful effect on the population, the environment and increase the greenhouse effect, which increases global warming. The European family must have a defensive position on massive pollution, adopt different mechanisms to increase the use of alternative energies. The problem is also felt at an industrial level, where there is a need for freight transport based on alternative fuels. We must also seriously think about the implementation in urban areas of public transport based on such energies. These movements will create a healthy environment and increase competitiveness across all sectors to find the best solutions. We need an ambitious and realistic policy if we want suitable infrastructure for alternative fuels. Let us look at the future - cleaner cities and countries, healthier and breathable air, protected oil resources and, what I consider most important for the life of every inhabitant, much healthier agricultural crops.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for this very interesting debate. We need even greater ambition and better collaboration among public and private players to speed up the deployment of an alternative-fuels infrastructure in the European Union that is available and easy to use for all consumers. We will do our share of the work and take further steps to improve consumer awareness and buy-in to this market. First, as part of the third Mobility Package, in May 2018 we will publish a common methodology for alternative-fuels price comparison. The idea is to inform consumers about the cost of driving for 100 kilometres in an alternative-fuel car versus a conventional car. The information will be displayed at petrol stations and via dedicated online tools, which we will help Member States to develop. Second, timely, reliable information about the location and availability of recharging points will have a major impact on consumer buy-in. We are therefore helping Member States in collecting information on the location and availability of charging points. This information will be available at national access points, to be freely used in consumer-friendly apps.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The fact that the fight against climate change has been intensifying in recent years is no longer in doubt. However, the question to which there are different answers is as follows: is it enough? The Paris Agreement is the most extensive agreement to protect the environment and combat climate change in history. Separately, this document is non-binding.
