It is necessary to ratify and implement it through concrete solutions. The Alternative Infrastructure Action Plan is a concrete case for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. At the same time, it is part of a major European strategy for decarbonisation. In 2017, in the context of the second mobility package, the Commission published a communication where it was clear that robust infrastructure for an alternative fuel is a key component of the strategy for decarbonisation and is inadequate in today's form. This means that if large-scale planning and building of this infrastructure is not started, the transition to decarbonized transport will be slowed down. It is now essential to reform this action plan and ensure that the necessary infrastructure is built.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in the Maldives (2018/2630 (RSP)).

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Madam President, I speak in my capacity as chair of the Delegation for relations with the countries of South Asia. We all deeply regret the state of affairs in the Maldives, not least as there are elections due in September this year. The people there deserve a free and full choice of candidates who can campaign robustly. I welcome reports in today’s news that the state of emergency there is unlikely to be extended, and I hope that turns out to be true. The issue of the judicial system is crucially important in events there and, looking at some of the recent events, many of us are left wondering about certain legal decisions and what has motivated them. There is a need for a credible and consistent system of justice, which is able to operate independently, regardless of who brings a case or who is accused. Courts should never be a political instrument for political parties, so we need the whole system to be free of harassment, intimidation and corruption, from wherever that comes. There is not only one source in this.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: author. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is yet another assault on democracy in that small paradise atoll in the Indian Ocean, a coveted destination for tourists all over the world, which has been swooping into chaos for years: I am talking about the Maldives. The arm wrestle now between the supreme court judges and President Abdullah Yameen, who pushed Parliament to declare a state of emergency in an illegal way, suspending valuable fundamental freedoms and kicking off a wave of arbitrary arrests. Notable among them is that of Justice Abdullah Saeed, chief justice of the Supreme Court. He and other political prisoners are denied the most basic rights: yesterday is the news that the government would even intercept the meetings between the judge and his lawyers, violating theirs right to confidentiality. Today, as always, we have a duty to support political opponents detained and in exile, such as former President Nasheed, the human rights defenders who suffer threats and persecution on the side every day governmental authorities, judges and lawyers, who are also victims of improper intimidation and interference. I call on the Maldives Government to immediately end the state of emergency, and the European Union to enforce the measures provided for in the Cotonou Agreements as well, and to block those responsible for this situation. If we don't act in a convinced way, we're complicit in Yameen, too.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, it is now almost three years since our first resolution in this Parliament in relation to the political crisis engulfing the Maldives. That resolution was a response to the 13-year prison sentence handed down to the country’s first democratically-elected President, Mohamed Nasheed, on trumped up terrorist charges, which were condemned by the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention. At that time, we criticised the politicisation of the judiciary and cautioned against any further backsliding on the rule of law. Three years on, the situation has significantly worsened. Freedom of expression, assembly and the press have been stifled, Members of Parliament and protesters have been routinely arrested, and now we see the country under state of emergency rule aimed at strengthening President Yameen’s hold on power.  Aside from the urgency of these domestic issues, we have seen repeated accusations of Maldivian-flagged vessels involved in oil transfers to North Korea and reports of an increasing numbers of citizens being recruited by ISIS/Daesh. It is vital that we see an end to the state of emergency now, see all elected Members of Parliament allowed to take up their seats, and find a course to ensure that genuinely free and fair elections can take place as scheduled in September 2018, with opposition candidate Nasheed being allowed to stand. We, in the European Union, must continue to apply pressure to achieve this outcome, and I welcome today’s resolution.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. — Madam President, this is the umpteenth resolution that concerns the Maldives, and I think that the situation has really not improved from what we know today, or, on the contrary, deteriorated. That is why I am very pleased that we agree on this resolution across political parties and across political currents in the European Parliament. So far, the European Union, I think, has sought a constructive dialogue with the leaders of the Maldives, even though it said what was wrong and what was wrong. At the moment, however, we have to accede to certain kinds of sanctions, it is impossible to wait further and look at what is happening in the Maldives today. It must be looked at that the human rights and political situation in the country is constantly deteriorating, that there is a restriction of human rights and freedoms, an expansion of the powers of the president, a polarization of justice. What we fear most is the reintroduction of the death penalty. Opposition leaders are pushing for the restoration of pluralistic democracy and rule of law. However, they are repeatedly subjected to attacks by authorities and police. There are even legal proceedings being fabricated against them. So it is necessary to call on all states active in the Maldives, including big players such as India and China, to cooperate with the European Union and try again to establish democratic principles in this country.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: author. — Madam President, Maldives is one of the most attractive and exclusive tourist destinations in the world and is also a key geostrategic point on trade routes in the region. But the reality for its inhabitants is very different from the paradise that is sold to us. The country is facing a political crisis that broke out in February as a state of emergency was decreed after the judiciary ordered the release of several opposition members. The state of emergency suspended constitutional guarantees and mechanisms for control and separation of powers; a situation that aggravates the climate of repression against freedom of expression and assembly, and persecution and attacks on political opponents, journalists and members of civil society, as well as human rights defenders. The European Union is one of the main trading partners of Maldives and therefore we have the means to act. We ask that this European Union does not take its commercial and geostrategic interests against the interests of the Maldivian people's classes and to act. Ladies and gentlemen, let it act.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Madam President, the declaration of a state of emergency in the Maldives, despite the peaceful protest of hundreds of citizens and international condemnation, has led to a large number of human rights and fundamental freedoms being suspended and abused. The authoritarian rule of President Abdulla Yameen is damaging the country and its people. Of grave concern is the threat of resuming state-sanctioned executions. The shift towards radical Islamism and increasing radical Islamist militancy is worrisome. The European Union must use all instruments to promote respect for human rights and democratic principles in the Maldives, even if that means suspending financial assistance or using targeted measures. The state of emergency should be lifted. Fundamental human rights and the rule of law must be respected. In the meanwhile, the EU also needs to coordinate its travel advice for European tourists.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: author. – Madam President, my Group is alarmed with the deterioration in human rights, democracy and rule of law in the Maldives, particularly in the run-up to the presidential elections. A functional parliament and an independent judiciary are fundamental pillars for a working democracy, therefore any interference with the work of the Supreme Court is unacceptable in a country that calls itself a young democracy. We call for the immediate lifting of the state of emergency and the implementation of the Supreme Court order to reinstate opposition MPs and release political prisoners. The state of emergency cannot be used as an excuse to violate the Constitution and crack down on members of civil society, the media, judges and political opponents. We encourage the regional actors to play a positive role in helping to resolve the political crisis in the Maldives. If the situation does not improve, we ask the EU to consider targeted measures in order to promote human rights and democratic principles. It is time for President Yameen to stop ruling with an iron fist and enter into a genuine dialogue with opposition parties and civil society, ensuring free and fair elections. It is in the interest of all Maldivians.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, we are of course concerned about recent political developments in the Maldives. That is why we, the PPE, have proposed these resolutions. President Yameen seeks to establish his authoritarian power in a brutal manner by annihilating any political opposition, seeking to use the judiciary as he wishes, and obstructing the independence of the press and civil society. His most recent act was the establishment of a state of emergency, which allowed it to suppress respect for fundamental freedoms. I believe that we must have a proportional response to the total deviation from any democratic principle of the Yameen regime. It would be important for a mission from this Parliament to go to the Maldives so that we could express our concern about the current political situation. In addition, we must join forces with those of other regional actors, such as India, to support a process of returning to democratic standards in the Maldives. I do not think we can join in this context with China, because Beijing cannot in any way be a partner for us in the field of democracy and human rights.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, threats, assaults, criminal prosecutions against the opposition and arrests are common in the Maldives. The rise in violence and human rights abuses are rightly denounced, but we must go back to the sources of this situation, which is the worst violence because it is perennial, because it is imposed on all. It is the one that is generated by the Sharia, by the full application of Islamic law. It ravines women to a lower rank, stigmatizes and persecutes Christian minorities. All this is against the freedom and dignity of man. In the Maldives, as in many Muslim countries, it is intrinsic evil. In the Maldives, it is the reverse side of the paradisiacal setting. In the Maldives, demonstrators can parade through the streets wielding Daesh flags. It makes Maldives today one of the biggest outfitters of terrorists in Syria and Iraq, those who murder with the most abject barbarity on our streets. We will always be surprised, in this House, which is gargling with human rights, that it is never denounced in the first place, wherever it is.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: — Madam President, behind the idyllic appearance of the Maldives is actually a dark reality. The human rights situation in the country continues to deteriorate. By using the proclaimed state of emergency and, above all, by instrumentalising it, President Yameen's teams are in the process of blatantly violating a large number of fundamental rights. I am thinking of freedom of assembly and association, freedom of expression and free access to independent and impartial justice. Of course, the European Union must use all the legal arsenal at its disposal to try to put an end to this situation. That is why I have chosen to follow without reservation the adoption of this resolution. But let us not be naive, let us not just state pious vows that will not impress the teams in place. That is why I would also like to take this opportunity to alert European public opinion by saying to them: 'Before you go there, know that the Maldives are no longer the paradise you believe at all. '

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to join my pre-speakers if they describe the situation in the Maldives. Indeed, our key concern should be free elections and courts that are independent and impartial. President Jamín is advancing against civil society, declaring a state of emergency, which may end, anyway, the declaration of a state of emergency itself has escalated the situation even further. I think it would take the European Union to act more at that diplomatic level to calm the situation. Maybe there's not too much we can do. We should also tell citizens that the sun-drenched sky where they spend their holidays is a country declaring a state of emergency that wants to impose the death penalty. I think these communications should reach our citizens very urgently, because the situation in the Maldives is very complex and is also the subject of certain great power struggles between China and India. If I have to choose whose side I am on in this situation, then of course I am on the side of the Maldives citizens and, say, pro-Western democratic India.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, a decade ago the first democratic elections and the adoption of a new constitution provided important cause for optimism on the path chosen by the Maldives. Democratic transitions take time, but as someone who has consistently called for strong EU support for the Maldives, it pains me to see the turn that has been taken over the past few years. Opposition, journalists, human rights activists, face attacks from authorities and extremists, and the recent state of emergency further encroaches upon the vital rights and freedoms. So my questions to the Commissioner are: what measures can we take to support the UN-facilitated dialogue between all parties in the Maldives in the run-up to the elections that have to take place this year? Secondly, do you share the concerns over reports that China has despatched a fleet of 11 warships to the East Indian Ocean in a sign of support to the Maldivian authorities, further increasing military build-up in the South China Sea? I would say it is crucially important that we have regional actors who are at play, and it is important that we get support for the S&D amendment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Maldives is a well-known tourist destination, but there is now a violation of fundamental rights on the agenda. We have an authoritarian regime of President Yamin, who is even taking advantage of the fact that he has declared a state of emergency and has thus gagged his political opponents, bloggers and journalists. But the Supreme Court in the Maldives has decided to reinstate at least a dozen deputies and give them their seats and annul various criminal charges against political opponents of the regime. It's something President Yamin doesn't like, and he wants to intervene in the Supreme Court. It is obvious that the influence of ISIS is now developing in this country, sharia is being applied, those with other religious beliefs are being persecuted. We must finally put an end to the arbitrariness of the regime.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Madam President, as some colleagues have pointed out in this Chamber, this is not the first time we have discussed the situation in Maldives. And it must be said that in that small country, which are the Maldives islands, there were still no minimum standards for democracy: human rights were not respected, judicial institutions were intervened by the Government and, moreover, politicians and journalists were persecuted for raising their voice against the Government of that small country - authoritarian and dictatorial, let's not forget. And that is why it is so important to support this motion for a resolution, Madam President, because we must remember that this country, the Maldives, receives a lot of economic aid from the European institutions and does not invest them either in democracy or in respect of human rights or religious freedom, but, far from that religious freedom, every time more, it is a nest of Daesh, of extremist jihadists who are engaged in exporting terror all over the world. Ultimately, it's an explosive paradise, Madam President.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, the Maldives case was already the subject of a resolution last October. We had been able to warn about the complicated situation in this country, which is experiencing an authoritarian political drift: the separation of powers is abused, the rights of religious minorities too, and the opposition is muzzled. Already serious, the situation has deteriorated with the establishment of the state of emergency and its extension on an unconstitutional basis and, now, with the threat of re-establishing the death penalty. It must be noted that the current president is raising pressure in the run-up to the elections to be held next fall. In this context, the European Union must be intransigent and make full use of all the instruments at its disposal to encourage the Government of Maldives to return to the norms of normal democratic functioning: ending the intimidation of the judiciary and journalists, releasing political opponents, respect the rights of minorities and respect the moratorium on the death penalty. Diplomatic firmness should, if necessary, be accompanied by financial sanctions and the freezing of foreign assets of certain officials.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the situation in the Maldives remains a source of concern. It has continued to deteriorate since our last debate. The European Union remains mobilised and has intensified its diplomatic actions to support democracy and the rule of law in the Maldives.  The country is an important partner for the European Union in the fight against climate change. As current Chair of the Alliance of Small Island States, the Maldives plays an important role in support of the Paris Agreement, and we are interested in deepening our cooperation in this field. At the same time, EU Member States are playing an active part in the development of tourism in the Maldives. In 2017, more than 645 000 tourists – almost 50% of visitors to the Maldives – came from Europe. We are also interested in developing cooperation on counter-terrorism and on countering violent extremism with the Maldives. However, the EU has closely followed the recent deterioration of the situation in the Maldives and immediately informed the authorities of its concerns. A statement was issued on 6 February in reaction to the declaration of the state of emergency by the Maldivian President. Our EU Ambassador was there to deliver an EU demarche from 19-21 February. He pressed for the restoration of the functioning of the parliament, called for an immediate lifting of the state of emergency and a return to constitutional normality, respect for constitutionally-guaranteed rights and the rule of law, and the immediate release of political prisoners. He also encouraged the UN-facilitated dialogue to allow for a political solution for the preparation of credible, inclusive and transparent presidential elections.  Upon my proposal, the Council adopted conclusions on the Maldives on 26 February. It was the first time, and it sent a strong political signal in support of the return to constitutional rule of the Maldivian authorities and people. The situation is not in accordance with the principle of democratic rule and separation of powers, and if this situation does not improve, the Council may consider targeted measures. The Council underlined that the parliament and the judiciary should be enabled to return to their normal functioning, in accordance with the Constitution, and called for the immediate lifting of the state of emergency and restoration of all constitutionally guaranteed rights. The Council condemned politically motivated arrests and called for the immediate release of all political prisoners.  Since the adoption of the conclusions, the situation has not yet improved. At the request of President Yameen, the parliament renewed, on 20 February, the state of emergency for an additional 30 days. A number of fundamental constitutional rights are still suspended. To date, there has been no release of political prisoners, and former President Gayoom, who is 81 years old, has not been released from house arrest.  We commend the deployment of an electoral follow-up mission, led by honourable Member of the European Parliament, Eduard Kukan, in January 2018, which carried out an assessment of the implementation of the recommendations of the 2014 EU Electoral Observation Mission. We are looking forward to Mr Kukan’s report and call for the competent Maldivian authorities to fully consider his conclusions, with a view to organising credible, transparent and inclusive elections. It is essential to restore constitutionally guaranteed rights and lift the state of emergency, as well as to respect and protect the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, including the freedom of expression and the right to fair trial. The EU encourages all stakeholders to work with the UN to facilitate such a dialogue, and the EU is ready to support UN facilitation. We will continue to closely follow the evolution of the situation, with a view to deciding on the next steps.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. The vote will be held at the end of discussions. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. — Young, because only ten years old, Maldivian democracy is currently experiencing a huge crisis. However, it should be emphasised that this crisis is not just the last few weeks, which are no doubt an escalation of the problem and are the most spectacular. The origins of the problems go back several years as President Yameen consolidated his authoritarian rule, banning peaceful demonstrations, arresting political oponents or shutting down independent media. I therefore believe that the European Union must intransigently demand the return of the rule of law and a real tripartition of powers and respect for human rights. To this end, the entire suite of tools available to us should be used, including the possible suspension of financial assistance to the Maldives or sanctions against specific persons. We must also keep a close eye on the upcoming presidential election — not only with regard to its course, but also the process of submitting candidates, because there are legitimate concerns that some of President Yameen's oponents will not be allowed to run in them.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the arrests of human rights defenders in Sudan, in particular on the case of Salih Mahmoud Osman, a Sakharov laureate (2018/2631 (RSP)).

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: author. — Madam President! Dear ladies! We are very concerned about the situation in Sudan. Human rights in Sudan are notoriously broken. Amid human rights abuses, a very difficult economic situation, price rises erupted earlier this year in which more than a dozen people were killed. Several dozen were injured. Hundreds of people, opposition leaders, journalists, students were arrested. They are held in prisons without facing charges and without trial. Sakharov Prize winner Salih Mahmoud Osman, a human rights defender, has been arrested. Therefore, through this resolution, we want to very strongly condemn the violence of the Sudanese regime against those involved in peaceful protests, and we also want to call on the Sudanese authorities to respect and protect fundamental human rights, including national, ethnic minorities and religious. The crisis in which Sudan is in, both economically and politically, will not end until basic human rights are violated. And we as the European Union are donating so much money to Sudan that we have the instruments to influence the Sudanese regime.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: author. — The case of Salih Mahmoud Osman, as well as examples of the use of force against people peacefully protesting, the restriction of freedom of speech and religion or the repression of journalists are evidence of the ongoing crisis of rule of law in Sudan. Torturing detainees, lack of information about the place of detention of Salih Osman and other activists, preventing them from having contact with lawyers or his family constitute serious abuses and are inconsistent with international standards. As it is known, some of the human rights activists were released from custody in February. But the forceful conditioning by the security services to release the remaining detainees and ensure they will not participate in further peace protests is contrary to Sudan's international human rights obligations. I therefore call for the immediate release of Salih Mahmoud Osman, a lawyer and recipient of the Sakharov Prize, and dozens of other activists who are being held because of their legal and peaceful work in defence of human rights and for democracy in Sudan.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: AUTHOR. — (FR) Madam President, we are here again to talk about Sudan, a country which repeatedly continues to violate fundamental rights since the accession of Head of State al-Bashir in 1989. The opportunity to talk about the scandalous situation of Salih Mahmoud Osman, a human rights defender and Sakharov Prize, must not overshadow the overall situation in Sudan, a country governed by a dictator, which is still under arrest warrant by the International Criminal Court for genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, where human rights defenders, political opponents or women's rights defenders are systematically locked up, a country that openly practices torture, muzzles the press, restricts the activity of NGOs or expels them without warning. It must be said and repeated: any form of cooperation with the Sudanese authorities violates obligations under international law and endangers the persons handed over by the European authorities to dictator Omar al-Bashir. Since the Khartoum process, Member States have been working openly with a criminal regime in managing migration policy in any shameful way. The European Union is putting more than $200 million as part of a broader strategy to outsource control... (the President interrupted the speaker)... migration. Cooperation with the Sudan must therefore be stopped.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: AUTHOR. — Madam President, at the end of 2017, Salih Mahmoud Osman, Sakharov Prize 2007, warned us in Brussels about the risks to human rights in Sudan, given the evolution of the European Union's cooperation with his country in the framework of the Khartoum process. In early January, when the country was again shaken by major peaceful protests against the rising cost of living, including commodities, he was arrested with more than 140 journalists, leaders and opposition activists, including those of the Sudanese Communist Party, activists, lawyers and human rights defenders. The sinister NISS (National Security and Intelligence Service) and the Rapid Security Forces, former Janjawids, act in disregard of the laws, including Sudanese, and it was precisely the NISS that arrested Salih Osman. He is diabetic and his health has deteriorated rapidly due to lack of care. He would be hospitalized. If relations between the European Union and Sudan make sense, if they serve something, then this is the time to show it and secure the release of Salih Osman and all political prisoners in Sudan. Commissioner, I'm counting on you.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: author. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, for exercising their right to peaceful protest, students, lawyers, demonstrators and human rights defenders have been arbitrarily arrested or even tortured. In 2007, we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Salih Mahmoud Osman, a human rights lawyer, for his fight against injustice in Sudan. For more than three decades, this lawyer has been struggling for the restoration of the rule of law in his country. The general human rights situation in the Sudan, as has just been said on several occasions, remains disastrous. The National Intelligence and Security Service outrageously abuses its extensive powers to restrict political and civil rights, including through intimidation, detention and torture. That is obviously not acceptable. I believe that the international community, through this resolution, must further strengthen the pressure on the Sudanese authorities.

name: Ana GOMES
text: author. – Madam President, Sakharov laureate Salih Mahmoud Osman came to the European Parliament last November to warn against the EU cooperating with tyrants under the Khartoum Process, namely with the brutal regime of Omar al-Bashir, who led wars against his own people in Darfur, in South Sudan. He was using EU funds and complacency and further repressing and oppressing the Sudanese, not deterring but instead making ever more migrants and refugees forced to flee misery and persecution. Salih was so right that he himself was again put in jail last month, as well as dozens of human rights defenders and civil society opposition activists. Well, all protests are violently silenced in Sudan. As a European, I am in pain and in shame for Salih and all the other brave Sudanese. Commission, Council and Member States: you will betray European values, interests and the trust of EU citizens and our African friends if you do not act immediately and decisively to get Sakharov laureate Salih Mahmoud Osman and all these brave Sudanese activists out of jail, and if you do not hear their warnings and their pleas to us, and if you do not get Omar al-Bashir, indicted as a criminal by the International Criminal Court (ICC), arrested and sent to trial.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, Sudan violates virtually all fundamental human rights. The European Union must support those in Sudan fighting to comply with them. I demand the release of all those who are unlawfully imprisoned because of human rights. The symbolic representative of all those imprisoned in this way is Saleh Mahmoud Smilmán, the recipient of the 2007 Sakharov Prize. Sudan punishes by imprisonment and torture the exercise of freedom of speech or freedom of assembly. It fundamentally restricts the existence or emergence of an independent press, restricts the activities of international humanitarian nonprofits. It does not adhere to freedom of religion. Yes, Sudan criminalizes blasphemy or transgression from Islam to another religion. Christians in Sudan are discriminated against and rely on our help. Sudan is the fifth worst country in the world in terms of securing freedom of religion.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. Sudan is an important country for Europe. The country is in transition and faces major challenges. It is home to millions of refugees and displaced persons, and it is relatively stable compared to its neighbouring countries. But this is a deceptive stability. It can only exist if the arbitrariness ubiquitous in that country is replaced by constitutional structures and human rights are respected. This is a long and long way to go. I was in Sudan with a delegation from the Subcommittee on Human Rights in December and I was convinced that many people are well aware of this problem. We also met with various human rights activists who shared their concerns, but also their hopes. They have all their hopes for Europe, particularly the European Parliament. That is why our resolution today, calling for the immediate release of Salih Mahmoud Osman, is so important and central.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! The actions of the authorities in Sudan in systematic repression of members of the democratic opposition and human rights abuses require a response from the international community. The imprisonment of Salih Mahmoud Osman is a garish, but unfortunately just one of many instances of violence by the Sudanese government. More than 140 other human rights activists and oppositionists have also been detained as a result of January's protests. The detentions proceeded with the use of force. We are also getting reports about the use of torture against those arrested. Dialogue with Sudanese authorities is needed, but it needs to be more forceful. However, I believe that when they ignore the recommendations of the international community, as if by rejecting the UN recommendation in May 2016, we should primarily target our support towards locally active human rights defenders and civil society. I believe that the European Union must support the United Nations and the African Union in this field.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I was humbled to meet Salih Mahmoud Osman last December when he came to visit the European Parliament. Ten years after receiving the Sakharov Prize, the arrest of Mr Osman is unacceptable. As part of a crackdown against free voices in Sudanese society, peaceful protesters demonstrating against rising prices are arrested. The situation in the country is very worrying, as widespread violations of human rights are reported on a daily basis. The High Representative must use all means at her disposal to urge the Sudanese authorities to release Mr Osman and all political prisoners. I also repeat my call to the EU and Member States to step up efforts in presenting Mr al-Bashir to the International Criminal Court. He must be brought to justice regarding the grave accusations of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity filed against him. I would also like to thank NGOs such as Front Line Defenders and Waging Peace, without whom we could not do our important work of standing up for human rights. Waging Peace in particular drew attention to Boris Johnson’s support of the UK-Sudan Trade and Investment Forum, billed as ‘an opportunity for foreign business and investors’. Be quite clear: there must be no trade that disregards human rights.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, the reason for our urgent resolution is the arrest of hundreds of people who are manifestating in Sudan for their human rights. Among those detained are academics, journalists, students and also campaigners for faiths rights, freedoms of creed, Christians. The best known name is attorney Saleh Mahmoud Smiling, who represents and advocates for human rights. He is seriously ill and lacks medical care. It also testifies that people in prison are being tortured, which is why we must raise our voice for Saleh Mahmoud Smiling to be freed as soon as possible. He urges us not to leave the people of Darfur, so we say to him: “Dear Saleh Smiles, we do not leave and call on the Sudanese government to immediately release you and others imprisoned. “

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, in a debate yesterday afternoon, I had occasion to say that European defence of freedoms requires journalists free from threats, but also lawyers and human rights activists free of threats. And that concerns the European Union's internal policy, when it comes to ensuring judicial cooperation and within the framework of the euroorder, in order to prevent impunity, but also to European foreign policy, which is obliged to face the release of Mahmoud Osman, winner of the Sakharov Prize in 2007, awarded by Human Rights Watch in 2017 and human rights activist and lawyer who has distinguished himself for legal defense and legal aid in the service of those who see their freedoms threatened in Sudan: activists, opponents, students, academics and journalists repressed. And this human rights activist pays it with repression and jail. The European Union is therefore obliged to use all its diplomatic and persuasive capacity and the weight of its external aid to ensure the early release of Mahmoud Osman.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to join the side of all my speakers who criticise the situation in Sudan and call very urgently for the liberation of not only Mr Smiling, but at the same time all imprisoned and unjustly tortured. Mr. Smiling is only one of many, I think his example is just meant to lead us to actually raise our voice very strongly. The situation in Sudan is insane, not just the economic one, but especially the situation in the field of protection of human rights. Actually, there are practically no human rights in Sudan. There are only those rights that correspond to the state establishment and its ideology there. I think that we should consider very strongly where we send our support in the form of money and whether it can be redirected, for example, to non-profit organisations that are facing very much in Sudan significant problems precisely in protecting the weak and disadvantaged.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the situation in Sudan continues to pose a threat to international peace and security in the region. Following the crackdown on peaceful protests, civil society and human rights defenders conducted by the Sudanese authorities, I strongly support the call for the unconditional release of Salih Mahmoud Osman, as well as any other human rights defenders and civil society activists who are being detained solely as a result of their legitimate and peaceful work.  All human rights defenders need to be able to perform legitimate human rights activities openly, without restrictions and without fear of reprisals. They have an essential role in ensuring democracy, human rights, the rule of law, stability and sustainable development, but this is probably too much for today’s Sudan. The Sudanese authorities have to put an end to targeting all human rights defenders and activists, conduct thorough investigations into all allegations of torture and ill-treatment, and bring the perpetrators to justice.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union is looking with growing concern at the human rights situation in Sudan, in particular, at freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. The nationwide protests against the rising commodity prices, which started earlier this year, have been met with an excessive use of force by the authorities. In recent months, we have witnessed a surge in arrests and detention of, among others, human rights defenders, journalists, student activists and members of the opposition, including leaders of political parties.  Media freedom has deteriorated further, with seizures of several newspapers. Among those arrested is Mr Salih Mahmoud Osman, a well-known Sudanese human rights lawyer and the laureate of the 2007 Sakharov Prize. Despite the release of dozens of detainees in mid-February, a move which the EU welcomed, more than 100 remain in detention. The EU delegation in Khartoum is doing its utmost to keep an updated logbook of all those detained.  Specific cases of concern, like that of Mr Salih, are closely monitored and systematically raised in meetings with the Sudanese authorities. The EU delegation in Khartoum has also met the families of those detained as well as the Sudanese Human Rights Commission, whose work it continues to support. Moreover, numerous EU local statements have been issued, urging the government of Sudan to respect freedom of expression and to release all political detainees.  Furthermore, on 27 February, the EU special representative for human rights, Mr Stavros Lambrinidis, called for respect for due process for all human rights defenders in Sudan, including Mr Salih, in his speech at the UN Human Rights Council.  I would like to thank Parliament for its continued engagement, illustrated not only by today’s debate, but also for the recent statement issued by Vice—President Hautala and Pier Antonio Panzeri, Chair of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, calling for the release of Mr Salih as well as the visit of the Subcommittee on Human Rights to Sudan last December. The protection and promotion of human rights remains at the core of the EU’s engagement with Sudan, and we will continue to staunchly condemn all abuses and support brave human rights defenders.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I rise to protest because you did not give me the floor in catch-the-eye. The fact that you missed time because you allow speakers to speak at least fifteen seconds is your problem, and that should not be at the expense of the speakers. I asked for the floor in good time, all the more so because I have signed this resolution, and I would ask you not to discriminate against the ECR next time.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr Marias, however, you must know that the President will ultimately have to assess how much catch-the-eye speeches can be granted, and I think you cannot complain that you would normally suffer this. Besides, there is no subjective right to catch-the-eye speeches. You are absolutely right that the President must ensure that the speaking times are upheld. It's true that in this conversation I've had to “violently” interrupt three speakers, that is, knocking the mace and closing the microphone, and that's not a good thing. The debate has ended. The vote will be held at the end of discussions. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – In 2007 we awarded human rights lawyer Salih Mahmoud Osman the Sakharov Prize. Now we must defend him as he has defended so many others. He, along with other human rights defenders, opposition party leaders, journalists and students are arbitrarily detained as Sudan’s president Omar al-Bashir takes criminal action against the rights and freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution he swore to protect. Sudanese armed forces and police kill students and peaceful protesters with live ammunition, and the human rights abuses in Sudan continue to increase. The Sudanese authorities must stop these atrocities, as well as stop confiscating newspapers, harassing and imprisoning journalists, and torturing detained persons. President Omar al-Bashir must ensure that international law is being followed, and call for the Sudanese Government to stop these violations in all accounts.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on five motions for a resolution on mercy killings in Uganda (2018/2632 (RSP)).

name: Marek JUREK
text: author. — Madam President! Europe should be a light to the world. And it's good that today we're talking about these horrific cases of so-called mercy killings in relation to disabled children in Uganda. And I hope that we will all, in accordance with this matter, take a resolution mobilising the Ugandan authorities to counter. Just the question arises: doesn't it remind us of something, or do we not see similar things in our own place? After all, a few months ago, the authorities of one of our largest countries, France, decided that it should not be granted social advertising status to an advertisement showing happy young people with Down syndrome. Why? Because as with this pagan superstition, it spoils well-being, their view badly affects. Let's really ask ourselves one simple question — hasn't the “kernel of darkness” moved into our old Europe these days?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Author. — Madam President, the killing “by grace” in Uganda was brought to our attention by a Belgian document and our colleague's personal testimony. We don't know exactly how common and widespread cases are, but anyway, it's a shocking thing to raise our voice against. We are, understandably, always against any kind of violence. The European Parliament should take a position on these inhuman practices in reports on the state of human rights, on the humanitarian crisis in Africa and the world. I have personally been finding out from people living in Uganda whether they have encountered cases of killing “by grace”, whether they can confirm them as a serious threat. It has been replied to me that there are such cases, health workers have encountered premature termination of pregnancy in the case of handicapped children or people with long-term illness are left to fate and die. Life is worthy of our protection from conception to natural end. That's why I raise my voice along with you against these practices. Please only assess for yourself whether this is an urgent resolution of the same urgency that we will adopt in order to immediately call on the Government of Sudan to release and stop the mistreatment prisoners in Sudan. As rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party, I therefore recommend abstaining in the vote, but at the same time I want to thank the draftsman, a colleague of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe that it brought the case to its attention. I'm not a formalist, it's not just that we lack specific names, events or testimonials. My point is that urgent reports remain an urgent and therefore powerful instrument of the European Parliament for immediate intervention. Whether we accept this report or not, I call for this discussion on the European Commission to monitor the situation, see how widespread this practice is and whether it is systemic, not haphazard matter. Based on these facts, the European Commission should then negotiate with the Ugandan authorities to stop unacceptable inhuman practice.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: author. — Madam President, the killing of disabled children in rural Uganda is due to the lack of a strong social state, and are not the only human rights violations occurring in Uganda. Extreme poverty is due to the control of the country by an oligarchy. President Museveni has been in power for thirty years. The European Union considered the last elections in which it won as fraudulent, and since then the country has increased its authoritarian tendency. Freedom of expression in Uganda does not exist: many critics of the Government were imprisoned, when they have not been killed. There are also political prisoners. The gender issue is dramatic: data on femicides are chilling. However, the European Union does not see this and supports the Ugandan Government as a partner acting as a stopper for migrants into Europe. In Uganda there are more than 1 million refugees from Sudan and Somalia. The European Union should take precedence over the promotion and respect of rights in its external action, and not subordinate such cooperation to its own geostrategic and security interests. We're tired of repeating it.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author. — (NL) Mr President, Karin is three years old. A terribly beautiful child, but born with clubfoot. She lives all alone with her mother in extreme poverty, because her father and the rest of the family have disowned them. Because a disabled child is a disgrace to the family in Uganda and many African countries. The mother is at the end of the matter. She's even considering to kill her child. Mercy killing, the so-called mercy killing to save herself and her child more suffering. Colleagues, this is a true story from Uganda — for those who would doubt it — recorded by investigative journalist Gerald Bareebe and brought to Europe by journalist Rudi Vranckx. For many — and I hear it here today — it's something like: does this exist? Is this true? It's so cruel that we have to ask ourselves if it's true. Because, ladies and gentlemen, I have no figures, there are no statistics, this is happening in the taboo sphere. This is, really, something nobody wants to talk about. So let us take a position here today. Let us give massive support to the resolution. Let's break the silence. Let us ask the European Commission to open an inquiry. Let us ask, Mr Michel, that the Committee on Development and Cooperation and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Sophie, that you take this up. Let us make sure that the aid organizations support families to break the taboo. All children, with or without disability, anywhere in the world, deserve a decent life.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Author. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the rights of children, all children, are inviolable. Hence our strongest condemnation of any kind of violation that disabled children are victims, not just in Uganda. We must eradicate these ritual crimes, oppose barbaric forms of superstition, fight against the beliefs that legitimize these horrible facts, unfortunately in support of the financial greed of people who they seek power. The Ugandan Government must increase its efforts, with the priority support of the European Union, to define and implement policies aimed at safeguarding and improving the conditions of children with children handicap, and also to include them fully in their society through laws that guarantee their safety, but also through services that preserve their integrity. These children are no different from the others. Disability must not lead to denial of basic civil and human rights, on the contrary.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, euthanasia in Greek means 'good death'. For active euthanasia, what is defined so in Uganda, we refer instead to brutal, violent, cruel murders, which in most cases concern children with disabilities, but also albinos and homosexuals. Something gruesome happens in Uganda, and little is known about this, but you know that the situation is worrying and reminds, in my opinion, the darkest and saddest period of Europe in the middle of the last century, and comes from feelings and motivations driven, in front of which we cannot stand by. It is about the failure to respect human rights, cases of children being abandoned to their fate. What does the EU do? What is done to ensure freedom of the press and that of women? It is necessary to intervene, to the government to demand respect for the rights of the person, especially the weakest, through a convinced and concrete support, as soon as possible.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, you are rightly outraged at the fate of many disabled children in Uganda who are euthanized because they are considered a weight to society. These acts more than shocking, monstrous, are absolutely revolting. And whether you want it or not, the emotion they create is a remnant of Christian ethics that many here reject. Unfortunately, as often, the protests we hear in this Chamber cannot hide the hypocrisy of Parliament. It is glad that you condemn the euthanasia of children in Uganda, but you remain silent when governments like Belgium and the Netherlands legalize euthanasia, including children. In this Union, which is gargling so much of human rights, a eugenist society is emerging, a society that admits that one can get rid of its former, but also of the disabled via prenatal screening. François Mitterrand's former adviser, Mr Attali, already said in 1981: “As soon as he exceeds 60-65 years, man lives longer than he produces and he costs society [...] Euthanasia will be one of the essential instruments of our future societies...” I think we're there.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would also like to support my colleagues if they were describing the deeds that are happening in Uganda. Killing “out of grace” is as cruel to me as murder. It is indeed something other than euthanasia and even that is somewhat questionable to me. I think this is shocking and every case is truly frightening, especially if it concerns those affected, if it touches superstitions that are very widespread in this state, touching albinos, homosexuals. I think it's important that we really find out how much frequent this negotiation is and it's our job not to lose sight of these negotiations after that and further pressure the government in Uganda. The pressure on the president must be strong because it will not only concern these negotiations, but also many political prisoners and the generally bad situation that is in Uganda.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, considering the hundreds of ritual killings of children – the so-called mercy killings of disabled children and women – that take place in Uganda each year, this is an abominable situation. It is incredible that, in the 21st century, we should face such a situation. The practice is taking place mainly among the rich elite. I would like to express my concern over the lack of data, which makes the fight against this practice very difficult. There are no official numbers available, as it is the police, and not the justice system, in Uganda who investigate these phenomena. I strongly condemn these cruel acts of violence, especially towards children, while I strongly share the opinion that it is primarily the responsibility of the state to protect its citizens, including the vulnerable. The European Union definitely has to address this situation, in one way or another, and especially with regard to the funds that the European Union is giving to the Ugandan Government.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, it is really very difficult to believe what is happening in Uganda. And yet it happens! It's not disputed. That they murder newborns or older children because they are disabled; other families abandon them, give them up to die. And these murderous practices are called “euthanasia”! These murderous practices must not only be condemned, but also punished, because there is a taboo in Uganda: to consider it a shame to have a child in a family who is disabled. I think that a decisive condemnation is needed, intervention by the European Union in this matter. And of course there is no evidence, because nobody mentioning it; because they allegedly consider it a practice which is happening. Well, this must be stopped and the Ugandan Government must be condemned immediately.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Madam President! My group is genuinely concerned about the lack of seriousness that this issue has been chosen as an urgency here. There is no evidence of the widespread use of the killing of disabled children in Uganda. We have heard it several times now, and only a documentary with individual cases was the basis for this decision. I don't mean to short the suffering of these children and these families. But a documentary film now means that Uganda is coming into the focus of the international public. Uganda, a poor country ready to take in more than a million refugees. I don't think that's a glorious sheet now when we're talking about Uganda. That is also the reason why we as a group did not co-sign this resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the behaviour and attitudes towards children and adults with disabilities in part of Uganda is truly horrifying, as has been said. Innocent children are marginalised, stigmatised, attacked and even murdered under the guise of ‘mercy killing’. What an unmerciful abuse of the word ‘mercy’! This is a clear and tragic case of extreme violation of the most fundamental human rights. Human rights groups have attempted to better the situation, but have at times fallen victim to violence themselves. I urge the Ugandan Government to cooperate with human rights organisations, and the EU, to develop and implement education, health and social programmes that will be effective in changing attitudes towards disabilities and supporting disabled people and their families. We cannot allow these gross abuses of human rights to continue. A huge cultural change is needed in Uganda and we must do all we can to bring it about.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, over the years, Ugandans and partners have expressed outrage at cases of child sacrifice, essentially perpetrated by witch doctors for certain rituals. Yet, there is an equally alarming practice referred to as ‘mercy killing’. This implies parents of children with disabilities killing their children or deliberately letting them die of starvation or through the denial of medical attention. Poverty and social stigma play a significant role, but not much information is available on the scale of the problem or the number of children concerned. In a recent documentary by a local TV station, some parents confessed to having engaged in mercy killings to save their children from severe suffering throughout their lives. Some also confessed to acts of mercy killing to save themselves from the difficulties of raising a child with a disability. Although Uganda’s legal framework provides for the protection of children, and specifically that of children with disabilities, only limited initiatives have been taken to avert the practice. This is partly attributed to the apparent social tolerance of such killings. The situation is further complicated by the fact that people with disabilities often face marginalisation and rejection. Such entrenched social barriers, coupled with inadequate support from communities and government, as well as families, can leave carers with the feeling of having no choice. The European Union, through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and other initiatives for the justice and law and order sector, provides support to the Government and to non-state bodies to address issues affecting children and discrimination against marginalised women and children. We ask the Government to address the problem of mercy killings. Parents of children with disabilities need support in providing special care for these children. The Government is encouraged to put in place adequate social services, medical care, special needs education and other facilities to enable children with disabilities to enjoy the same rights as any other children. The Government should, furthermore, ensure that the perpetrators of mercy killings are brought to justice. The EU stands ready to work with the Government of Uganda in addressing this issue.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. The vote will be held at the end of discussions. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - The protection and proper assurance of human rights is the responsibility of each state and the basis for sustainable development. Effective action must be taken as soon as possible to effectively prevent the practice of killing children with disabilities, derived from the belief that such children are better to die than to suffer from a painful and incurable disability. Mothers who have not quenched the disabled are condemned by society. The current problem should be addressed through quality educational and scientific tools, such as seminars and special training for adults, including lectures on the right of healthy development of people with disabilities in society in the school and higher education programme. It is also necessary to promote political cooperation with Uganda in support of the country's government, NGOs and civil society efforts to develop and implement policies aimed at the needs and rights of people with disabilities.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Mr President, millions of animals are dragged throughout Europe every day. They are waiting for days at the external borders of Europe in the scorching sun. One million citizens have asked for an end to this situation. 223 Members of this House have asked for a special committee of inquiry. This morning, three members in the front row decided not to. And I only have three words for that: shame on you!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you. I will forward your comments to the President of Parliament.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Madam President, PSOL councilor Marielle Franco was murdered tonight in Rio de Janeiro. A feminist, human rights, anti-capitalist activist has been murdered; an activist murdered in a climate of pre-electoral political violence in Brazil. From here, our solidarity with your colleagues and colleagues and, above all, our firm condemnation from the European Parliament to this climate of violence in Brazil.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to tell you and the Presidency that yesterday a truly unbelievable fact took place in this building, because during the press conference of one of our former colleague, Mr Salvini, the claque behind Mr Salvini prevented the press from asking questions and the press from asking the things that needed to be asked. They were also physically threatened by journalists inside this building, journalists were prevented from asking questions. I ask that you intervene on this.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, I am speaking on behalf of my colleagues, Julie Girling, Molly Scott Cato, and myself. We all represent Salisbury, in the south-west of England. It is also the city where I live. As British pro-EU MEPs, the Brexit resolution meant this has been a difficult week, but the unwavering solidarity ... (Interruption by the President)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Could I just say to you that this is a disgrace. The lady is making a statement about a serious issue. Please listen. (Applause)

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, as I said, as British pro-EU MEPs, the Brexit resolution meant this has been a difficult week, but the unwavering solidarity we have received from this Chamber, in the face of the nerve agent attack, has been deeply appreciated. Our constituents will be reassured by your determination to work with us to ensure their future security. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Ms Moody. You can hear the applause. Excuse me, Madam, I am going to call you. Madam Atkinson would you please take the floor now – with a point of order I hope.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, can I ask whether Ms Moody condemns her party leader for not condemning what is going on in Russia, and I would say to you, colleagues, I’m flying to Russia this afternoon ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, this is not question time or a debate. I will now move to the vote.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have started the vote so I am going to go through this vote.  Mr Coburn, I am going to continue this vote. I will come to you at the end. Please resume your seat.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, thank you. That was very gracious. It is a serious point of order. Ms Moody’s was not a point of order. This was a political speech, not a point of order, and she should not have been allowed to do that.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: Madam President, it seems to me that we did not vote, in paragraph 7, the original text, which would invalidate the result of the vote. Check it out, please.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Just to clarify that we voted on amendment 3, which was adopted, and therefore the original text fell. Thank you for double checking.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament cannot be called upon to put stamps on other people's decisions, inter alia informally taken on the sidelines of ministerial meetings without a legally binding legal basis, and on top of that through a draw. For these reasons, together with colleagues from all the political groups, whom I thank for their cooperation, we decided to remind the prerogatives of co-legislator of the European Parliament and insist on the full compliance with the ordinary legislative procedure in relation to the location of European bodies and agencies. Indeed, as the only directly elected institution representing the citizens of the Union, Parliament is the first guarantor of respect for the democratic principle, and we intend to make this principle our own today's vote, in which we say yes to the location identified, but a yes conditional on compliance with the rules and times necessary to ensure the full operation of the agency. This, though, as far as we're concerned, will be the last time. We are waiting for a discussion in the negotiations to reiterate the role that the European Parliament deserves and which is recognised by the Treaties.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I ask for the referral of the matter back to the committee for interinstitutional negotiation in accordance with Rule 59, paragraph 4, subparagraph 4.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, have we voted on paragraph 39?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Yes we did.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: Madam President, I would ask you, pursuant to Rule 190 (4) of the Rules of Procedure, to agree to postpone the voting on this point and, of course, to delay the amendment phase by extending the deadline for its submission. The reason for this is that we have had almost 36 hours to work on such an important issue on behalf of the Conference of Presidents and we have come to the conclusion — the vast majority of groups — that, on such a delicate, new, complex and important issue, such as corporate social responsibility, probably we will be able to reach — I say this as coordinator responsible for trying to achieve a common resolution — at least more common points if we can debate more time. I therefore ask honourable Members to accept, on the basis of that Article, the postponement of the vote.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Could I ask for your attention for a special announcement please. Members, we often forget those who work in this House. I would ask Mr José Holguera to stand, please. This is his last day in Strasbourg before retirement. (Applause) This gentleman – because this is a gentleman, I have checked his credentials – has been in charge of the plenary Minutes and has worked for Parliament, mostly for plenary sittings, for 32 years. Mr Holguera, enjoy your break and thank you for your services. (Sustained applause)

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, I supported the report on the reform of a common framework for providing better services in the area of skills and qualifications, because it focuses on two very important points. First of all, we must note that in their current form Europass documents are used mainly by highly educated people at the expense of the permanently unemployed, low-skilled and disabled people. One of the objectives of the reform is precisely to improve accessibility. Every young person, regardless of the economic and social situation in which he is in, should have equal access to the opportunities for internships and work. Secondly, we all know how important the CV is when applying for a job. Skills gained from volunteering or staying abroad, for example, can prove much more valuable to an employer than an additional master's degree. With the reform, the Europass CV will be personalised, meaning young people will be able to highlight their skills and competences that they have acquired outside school or university.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, I voted in favour of this very important Europass report because it is an important online platform for consolidating European Union resources relating to skills and qualifications, self-assessments and information on training opportunities in the European Union. With the modernisation of the text, all our citizens will be able to use the extended portal with electronic tools to document and present all their skills and qualifications, as well as educational and professional experience. The revamped instrument will greatly simplify educational and professional mobility across Europe, which is absolutely necessary. Our priorities in the negotiations were personal data protection, increased visibility on the platform and the highest standards of accessibility for people with disabilities. You will see them reflected in the final version of the text. It is important that our citizens have the best and easy-to-use tools to show their skills and qualifications in the best possible light.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report. I welcome revision of the Europass framework and the opportunity to increase transparency of skills and qualifications across Europe. Europass is the top European initiative for documenting skills, qualifications and professional experience. This report is a significant step in ensuring we use this framework to the best of our ability for the benefit of all EU citizens. The revision of Europass brings with it many important advantages. It will allow for the inclusion of non-formal skills and newer skills such as digitalisation. Development of the framework will allow citizens to use online services, such as the creation of an e—portfolio and skills assessment.
